abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey a satisfactory
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. Project results largely
            confirm that the establishment of a flexible mechanism for
            financing demand-driven training activities to strengthen
            labor force qualification, is a viable and interesting
            response to the skills development needs of various economic
            actors, especially in the informal sector. However, project
            implementation underscored that success and sustainability
            hinge on some key elements. Lessons are highlighted as
            follows. The effectiveness and sustainability of mechanisms
            depend heavily on the autonomy granted to the fund, and on
            the extent of private sector "ownership." And, the
            credibility of the mechanism calls for the establishment of
            an adequate-and predictable-system of funding. The
            demand-driven approach, and the organization of fair
            competition among training providers underline the need to
            be able to manage activities smoothly within a predictable
            short- and medium-term framework to sustain training demand,
            and to expedite timely responses to the needs identified.
            Ensuring availability of other inputs such as micro-finance
            and market accessibility is essential to improve the impact
            of training on beneficiaries, especially in the informal
            sector. But, financing a demand-driven training program,
            together with the required beneficiary contribution should
            be accompanied by adequate evaluation work, and suitable
            communication strategies to ensure equitable distribution of grants.
